Crimes.Crime_Name: Serious Non-Political Crime under the United Nations Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether serving a sentence for a serious non-political crime prior to entering Canada exempts an individual from Article 1F(b) exclusion
Crimes.Governing_Law: Article 1F(b) of the United Nations Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review by the Federal Court
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant's U.S. conviction for drug offenses, sentence served (29 days in jail), and unserved probation period
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate they are not excluded under Article 1F(b)
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant left the U.S. before completing probation, raising concerns about compliance with legal obligations
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Article 1F(b) excludes individuals who committed serious non-political crimes outside the country of refuge; assessed under Canadian standards of seriousness
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Refugee status claim based on fear of persecution
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature and severity of the offense under Canadian law, maximum penalty (life imprisonment), incomplete sentence
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, United Nations Refugee Convention
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Claimed refugee status despite prior criminal conviction
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Criminal record, sentencing documents, probation status

Crimes.Claimant_Status: Failed refugee claimant with pending applications

Crimes.Evidence_Used: Refugee and PRRA decisions, sponsorship application status
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of clear evidence of irreparable harm
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No reviewable error found in officer's assessment
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Delay in enforcement of removal order
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Tri-partite test (serious issue, irreparable harm, balance of convenience)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Public interest in enforcing removal orders outweighs individual circumstances

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to comply with conditions of stay
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 24(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant failed to maintain legal status; submitted spousal sponsorship without approval
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Rejected refugee claimant with pending sponsorship
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court review of removal decision
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Negative refugee and PRRA decisions, sponsorship application details
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Speculative claims of harm without supporting evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claims not substantiated with credible evidence
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal based on humanitarian considerations
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Tri-partite test for stay of removal
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Public interest in prompt enforcement of immigration laws
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Canada Border Services Agency (CBSA), Federal Court

Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Potential hardship upon return to Venezuela
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: Low to moderate (assault charge mentioned but no conviction details)
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Assessed as low in context of removal
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavits, procedural records
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Low credibility due to lack of corroboration
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: Not applicable – focus on immigration consequence

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with court order

Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Pending applications and fear of harm in home country
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Negative refugee determination, PRRA refusal, lack of travel fitness issues
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Minister opposed stay citing public interest
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Administrative decisions, affidavits

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Adverse credibility due to inconsistencies in PIF, police denunciation, and medical report
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA - Convention refugee or need for protection
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inconsistencies and unexplained omissions in documentation

Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Minor error in interpretation of medical report
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to credibility assessment

Crimes.Application_Factor: Failure to provide credible explanation for discrepancies

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of RPD's credibility findings
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Adverse credibility due to multiple discrepancies in denunciation and PIF
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA - Proof of persecution or risk of harm
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Omitted police interactions, inconsistent dates/times, lack of corroboration

Crimes.Document_Fraud: False or misleading denunciation submitted as evidence

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to disclose material fact in immigration application
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether failure to disclose a child constitutes a material misrepresentation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Plaintiff admitted omission; not deemed innocent mistake
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Immigration application, personal testimony, family circumstances
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Omission of dependent child in application
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Materiality of the omitted fact on immigration decision
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review of administrative appeal decision
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness of the Appeal Division's decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Misrepresentation of a material fact under s. 27(1)(e)
Crimes.Application_Factor: Potential impact of disclosed family member on eligibility
Crimes.Document_Fraud: No forgery, but false statement by omission

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Revocation of landing due to misrepresentation
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether omission of a child amounts to misrepresentation affecting permanent residence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Admission of omission; claim of innocence rejected
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Immigration application, admissions, hardship claims
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Acquisition of permanent residence through incomplete disclosure
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Materiality and intent inferred from concealment
Crimes.Application_Error: Intentional or negligent omission of dependent child
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None found – full consideration given to mitigating factors
Crimes.Application_Factor: Impact of undisclosed family member on admissibility
Crimes.Document_Fraud: False statement by omission in application

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making a false statement under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can the applicant's pre-removal risk assessment (PRRA) be upheld based on new evidence or risks?
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant lacked credibility; claim dismissed due to credibility issues
Crimes.Evidence_Type: New evidence of deteriorating country conditions and personal risk as a failed refugee with forged ID
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Risk of persecution and cruel treatment upon return to Sri Lanka
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of credible, specific evidence showing serious risk
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to provide sufficient new evidence that was not reasonably available earlier
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Serious possibility of persecution or danger under IRPA s. 96/97
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None explicitly ignored; assessed as insufficient
Crimes.Application_Factor: Changed country conditions and status as failed refugee
Crimes.Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court of Canada
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Use of forged identity document noted but not independently prosecuted

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of a forged identity card
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Risk assessment upon removal to home country
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Is the applicant at risk of persecution or harm upon return to Sri Lanka due to possession of a forged identity card?
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claimant's overall credibility undermined by prior inconsistencies and lack of evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Alleged risks related to use of forged ID and state scrutiny in Sri Lanka
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 97 of IRPA (risk of torture or cruel and unusual treatment)
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of punishment by Sri Lankan authorities for immigration document fraud
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Absence of concrete evidence linking forged ID to probable risk of torture or death
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Pre-removal risk assessment and judicial review
Crimes.Application_Error: Did not demonstrate that risk stemmed directly from the forged ID
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Serious possibility of danger under IRPA s. 97
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Generalized country condition reports without personalization
Crimes.Application_Factor: Status as failed refugee and use of fraudulent documents
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; applicant must return to Sri Lanka
Crimes.Authority: Canada Border Services Agency, IRB, Federal Court
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Confirmed possession of forged identity card

Crimes.Violation_Type: Re-entry and removal risk after failed refugee claim
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Sections 96 and 97 of IRPA regarding post-claim risk assessment
Crimes.Application_Facts: Claimant asserted worsened conditions in Sri Lanka and personal vulnerability as a returned failed refugee
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Failed refugee claimant seeking protection via PRRA
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Remained in Canada post-refusal; subject to removal
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Use of forged ID and credibility concerns during initial claim
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Availability and timeliness of new evidence for PRRA
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over PRRA judicial review
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Country condition updates, individual circumstances, PRRA submissions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to prove individualized risk beyond speculative possibility
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility affecting weight of new claims
Crimes.Outcome: Removal order enforceable; no protection granted
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal and protected person status under PRRA
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious possibility of persecution or danger under IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No substantial change in country conditions or personal circumstances demonstrated
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC), CBSA, IRB

Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Credibility determination based on impermissible speculation
Basis_for_Decision: Implausible findings on delay, lack of immediate killing, nickname inconsistency

Sub_Crime_Type: Death threats as part of gang extortion
Prior_Criminality: MS-13 known for violent criminal activity
Evidence_Sufficiency: Contested by RPD, found reasonable by court
Credibility_Assessment: RPD's negative credibility finding deemed unreasonable

Evidence_Sufficiency: Contested by RPD, upheld by court

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did Paul Chun commit contempt of court by knowingly violating an Anton Piller order prohibiting the sale of counterfeit Louis Vuitton products?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Contempt of court law, trademark protection statutes
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Evidence showed sales at a night market in September 2000 and from his van in August 2001; photographs and witness testimonies were presented
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Chun acknowledged the order and shrugged when confronted, indicating awareness and lack of remorse
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Contempt of court occurs when a person disobeys a court order, proven beyond a reasonable doubt, requiring knowledge and willful disobedience
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Proof of disobedience to a valid court order with knowledge
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Violation of Anton Piller order prohibiting sale of counterfeit goods
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Chun found guilty of violating the court order twice
Key_Evidence_Considered: Service of Anton Piller order in July 2000
Sales at night market (September 2000)
Sales from van (August 2001)
Chun's acknowledgment of the order
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Federal Court rules on injunctions and contempt
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Acknowledged the order but continued selling; shrugged when confronted
Crimes.Outcome: Fined $50,000 and ordered to pay $35,000 in costs; potential imprisonment if unpaid within 90 days
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Anton Piller order under Federal Court jurisdiction

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did Paul Chun knowingly disobey a court order prohibiting the sale of counterfeit Louis Vuitton products?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Law of contempt, enforcement of court orders
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Court evaluated testimony and physical evidence of post-order sales
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Chun admitted knowledge of the order but engaged in prohibited conduct
Crimes.Legal_Rule: A person is guilty of contempt if they knowingly disobey a court order. Elements: existence of order, knowledge, and deliberate disobedience
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Clear and convincing evidence of willful violation
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Chun found guilty for two separate violations after the order
Key_Evidence_Considered: Service and acknowledgment of Anton Piller order
Undercover operations documenting sales
Photographic and testimonial proof of distribution
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Admitted awareness but failed to comply; nonchalant attitude upon confrontation
Crimes.Outcome: $50,000 fine and $35,000 in costs; possible 60-day imprisonment if unpaid
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Inherent jurisdiction of court to punish contempt

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did Paul Chun commit civil contempt by violating the court order prohibiting him from selling counterfeit Louis Vuitton products?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Trademarks Act, common law contempt principles
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Evidence demonstrated ongoing commercial sale of infringing goods after binding order
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Found in violation of court order (civil contempt)
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Beyond a reasonable doubt (for criminal contempt); clear and convincing for civil contempt
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Chun confirmed the order was still in effect but disregarded it
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Civil contempt requires: existence of a court order, knowledge by defendant, and knowing disobedience
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Continued sale of counterfeit branded goods post-injunction
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Liability established for repeated infringement activities
Key_Evidence_Considered: Anton Piller order served July 2000
Documented sales events in 2000 and 2001
Defendant’s admission of order’s validity
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Intellectual property enforcement via equitable remedies
Crimes.Defendant_Response: No defense raised; tacit admission through conduct
Crimes.Outcome: Sanctioned with $50,000 fine and $35,000 costs; subject to incarceration if unpaid
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section of Trademarks Act related to unauthorized use; court’s equitable powers

Dispute_Type: Patent infringement dispute between brand-name and generic drug manufacturers
Legal_Issue: Whether the generic drug manufacturers infringed the '380 Patent for lovastatin
Governing_Law: Section 5 and Section 6 of the Patented Medicines (Notice of Compliance) Regulations
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review under the Patent Act and associated regulations
Evidence_Assessment: Applicants' contamination argument rejected; evidence showed Coniothyrium fuckelii alone produced significant yield improvements; sterilization procedures deemed adequate
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicants to show that non-infringement allegations were justified
Credibility_Factor: Applicants' allegations found unjustified on a balance of probabilities
Legal_Rule: Section 5 and 6 of the Patented Medicines (Notice of Compliance) Regulations govern allegations of non-infringement and prohibition orders
Grounds_for_Claim: Merck Frosst claimed generic manufacturers would infringe their patent by producing lovastatin using Coniothyrium fuckelii
Outcome_on_Merits: Respondents' non-infringement allegations justified; applications dismissed
Key_Evidence_Considered: Yield data from Coniothyrium fuckelii; adequacy of sterilization procedures; absence of Aspergillus terreus contamination
Legal_Framework: Patent Act, Patented Medicines (Notice of Compliance) Regulations
Defendant_Response: Generic manufacturers alleged non-infringement based on contamination claims and alternative production methods
Evidence_Type: Scientific and technical evidence, process documentation, microbiological data
Remedy_Requested: Prohibition orders against generic manufacturers to prevent market entry
Outcome: Applications dismissed; costs awarded to respondents
Legal_Provision: Section 5 and 6, Patented Medicines (Notice of Compliance) Regulations
Authority: Federal Court (implied by judicial review under Patent Act)

Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical residency requirement
Application_Facts: Respondents accumulated only 22 and 60 days of physical presence in Canada within four years preceding application
Misrepresentation_Element: Claim of maintaining permanent residence in Canada without substantial integration into Canadian society or institutions
Procedural_Issue: Secretary of State appealed Citizenship Court's decision
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence of integration into Canadian society or institutions
Credibility_Assessment: Claim of permanent residence deemed insufficient due to lack of integration
Decision_Outcome: Appeals allowed, Citizenship Court's decision rescinded
Remedy_Sought: Appeal by Secretary of State to Federal Court
Legal_Standard_Applied: Three years of physical residence in Canada within four years preceding application under s. 5(1)(b)
Decision_Rationale: Respondents did not meet statutory residency requirement; minimal physical presence and lack of integration undermine claim of residency

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Acosta remained in Canada beyond the authorized period of stay.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of refugee claim rejection
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Assessment of risk under Canadian immigration law
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Evidence of generalized violence in Honduras and specific gang threats
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence to distinguish personal risk from generalized violence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credible fear but risk not individualized
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Risk faced was consistent with general conditions in Honduras, not uniquely personal

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act - reporting requirement upon entry
Crimes.Application_Facts: Acosta entered Canada without reporting to Customs/Immigration authorities
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Admissibility and assessment of claim despite irregular entry
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Testimony and documentation regarding entry and gang threats
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of proof of legal entry or reporting
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Fear acknowledged but entry non-compliant
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Failure to report does not automatically disqualify, but risk not found to be personalized

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee protection claim following irregular entry
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether Mr. Acosta faced a personalized risk justifying protection
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credible fear but risk not distinct from general population
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary and testimonial evidence of gang targeting
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution by criminal gang
Crimes.Application_Error: Irregular entry and failure to report
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to Board’s decision
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None identified – Board considered all relevant evidence
Crimes.Application_Factor: Individual targeting within context of widespread violence

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of the Minister's certificate alleging terrorist affiliation
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Federal Court review under s. 40.1 of the Immigration Act
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Assessed on balance of probabilities; included confidential intelligence and testimony
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Singh's denials were deemed incongruous and not credible
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Court must determine if there are reasonable grounds to believe membership in a terrorist organization
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Minister issued certificate based on security intelligence reports
Key_Evidence_Considered: Involvement with Sikh militant groups
Financial support to families of hijackers
Interaction with BK leaders
Sheltering wife of former BK leader
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Denials presented but found not credible
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review to challenge the certificate
Crimes.Outcome: Certificate upheld; Singh considered inadmissible under immigration law

Crimes.National_Security_Element: Affiliation with BK/BKI, a designated Sikh militant group
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential threat due to association with terrorist organization
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: High risk based on close associations and support activities
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Sustained contact with known militants and leadership figures
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Supportive and associative conduct indicating membership
Crimes.Target_Entity: Canadian national security and immigration integrity
Admission_or_Involvement: Sheltered wife of former BK leader
Received calls from Wadawa Singh Babbar
Had significant ties with BK/BKI leaders
Crimes.Leadership_Role: No formal leadership role established, but active supporter
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Court found applicant's explanations inconsistent and lacking credibility
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Credibility of Singh’s denials versus intelligence and circumstantial evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Denials deemed incongruous and not credible
Credibility_Factors: Lack of plausible explanation for contacts
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Challenge to ministerial certificate on judicial review
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Declared inadmissible; subject to removal from Canada

Crimes.National_Security_Element: Support for a proscribed terrorist organization
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Endangerment through material and logistical support
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Ongoing risk due to sustained connections and supportive acts
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Association with individuals involved in violent extremism
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Non-combat support including shelter, communication, and financial aid
Admission_or_Involvement: Provided indirect support to militant network
Crimes.Leadership_Role: Supporter without evidence of operational command
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Applicant’s explanations rejected due to inconsistency
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Weight given to classified evidence and behavioral patterns
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Denials lacked plausibility and coherence
Credibility_Factors: Actions consistent with support for militant cause
Crimes.Governing_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act – terrorism-related inadmissibility
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of national security certificate
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Certified as inadmissible; threat to national security confirmed

Crime_Name: Judicial Review of Immigration Officer's Decision
Legal_Issue: Whether the immigration officer breached procedural fairness by using undisclosed extrinsic evidence
Evidence_Assessment: Immigration officer conducted an internet search on services in Mexico without notifying applicants
Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to demonstrate procedural unfairness
Credibility_Factor: Officer's reliance on non-disclosed external information affects credibility of decision process
Legal_Rule: Procedural fairness requires disclosure of significant and novel information to allow response from affected parties
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness, depending on jurisdictional context
Grounds_for_Claim: Procedural unfairness, use of speculative findings, failure to disclose evidence
Outcome_on_Merits: Not decided on substantive merits; remitted for re-examination
Key_Evidence_Considered: Undisclosed internet research on conditions in Mexico
Legal_Framework: Administrative law, principles of natural justice, procedural fairness
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of decision, re-assessment by another officer
Outcome: Case remitted for reassessment by a different immigration officer
Authority: Court conducting judicial review of administrative decision

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration inadmissibility based on alleged complicity in international crimes
Crimes.Outcome: Finding of complicity deemed unreasonable; case remitted for re-determination
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged personal and knowing participation in or association with EPLF's crimes against humanity
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), principles of complicity and individual criminal responsibility under international law
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Judicial review allowed, complicity finding overturned
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Immigration Division's inadmissibility determination subject to judicial review
Crimes.Jurisdiction: Canadian immigration law with reference to international legal standards
Crimes.Protected_Group: Civilians affected by attacks on food convoys and ethnic expulsions
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Eritrea at the time lacked effective state protection mechanisms during conflict
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Membership in armed liberation movement linked to atrocities
Crimes.Credibility: Board erred in assuming knowledge from general support; lack of direct evidence of awareness or participation
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Not applicable — non-state actor (EPLF) responsible for acts
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Serious harm including deprivation, forced displacement, and violence

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration inadmissibility based on organizational affiliation
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether mere membership in EPLF triggers inadmissibility under terrorism provisions
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of administrative decision by Immigration Division
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Evidence established long-term membership and EPLF’s engagement in terrorist acts
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Inadmissibility upheld based on membership alone
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On state to show reasonable belief in organization's terrorist activity and individual membership
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Claimant's lack of knowledge of specific acts not relevant under IRPA 34(1)(f)
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Membership in an organization reasonably believed to engage in terrorism renders individual inadmissible
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness standard applied to administrative decision
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Affiliation with EPLF, which conducted kidnappings and attacks on civilian ships
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim of inadmissibility on terrorism grounds sustained
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Duration and nature of Mr. Hagos’ EPLF membership, documented EPLF terrorist activities
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), anti-terrorism provisions
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Mr. Hagos claimed unawareness of EPLF’s terrorist conduct
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary and testimonial evidence regarding EPLF operations and membership records
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review seeking cancellation of inadmissibility finding
Crimes.Outcome: Partial success: terrorism-based inadmissibility upheld, crimes against humanity finding set aside
Crimes.Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court on judicial review

Crimes.Violation_Type: Immigration violation due to failure to depart after visa expiration
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant is a U.S. citizen who remained in Canada beyond the authorized period and has prior U.S. convictions
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to comply with departure notice
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of adjudicator's decision on equivalency and stay of deportation
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of Canadian immigration authorities to enforce deportation
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Adjudicator's determination, applicant’s criminal record, Black's Law Dictionary
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Motion for stay of deportation dismissed
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of deportation based on irreparable harm and balance of convenience
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Requirement to prove irreparable harm and favorable balance of convenience for stay
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Arrest in U.S. due to own wrongdoing does not constitute irreparable harm; separation from fiancée insufficient for threshold

Crimes.Crime_Name: Conviction for burglary (equivalent to Canadian offence)
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Equivalence of foreign conviction to Canadian criminal offence
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether U.S. burglary conviction is equivalent to an offence under the Canadian Criminal Code
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Use of Black's Law Dictionary to determine legal equivalence
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: No error found in adjudicator's equivalence determination
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show error in equivalence or grounds for stay
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant's argument that lack of counsel input was prejudicial
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Foreign convictions equivalent to Canadian offences may lead to deportation
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged legal error in using dictionary without legal counsel input
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Guilty plea to California Penal Code offences, dictionary definitions
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Comparative analysis of U.S. misdemeanour and Canadian indictable offences
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Argued flawed methodology in determining equivalence
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, statutory interpretation
Crimes.Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board / Federal Court

Crimes.Crime_Name: Conviction for theft (equivalent to Canadian offence)
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Equivalence of foreign conviction to Canadian criminal offence
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether U.S. theft conviction is equivalent to an offence under the Canadian Criminal Code
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Use of Black's Law Dictionary to assess legal equivalence
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: No error found in adjudicator's decision
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate legal error or irreparable harm
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant’s claim of unfair process due to lack of counsel during equivalence assessment
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Foreign convictions equivalent to Canadian crimes justify deportation
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Challenged method of determining equivalence and right to respond
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Guilty pleas to California misdemeanours, adjudicator's interpretation
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Assessment of foreign offence alignment with Canadian Criminal Code
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Contested validity of using dictionary without legal representation
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Statutory records, legal reference materials
Crimes.Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board / Federal Court

Dispute_Type: Classification of farming activities for tax deduction purposes
Legal_Issue: Whether the plaintiff was a 'class (I) farmer' entitled to deduct farming losses under s. 31 of the Income Tax Act
Governing_Law: Section 31 of the Income Tax Act
Evidence_Assessment: Plaintiff's time spent on farming, capital investment, borrowing, reduction in reliance on managerial job, impact of drought and economic conditions
Decision_Outcome: Judgment in favor of the plaintiff
Burden_of_Proof: Plaintiff demonstrated commitment to farming as chief source of income
Credibility_Factor: Plaintiff moved to farm, invested savings, worked long hours, borrowed heavily
Legal_Rule: A taxpayer is a 'class (I) farmer' if farming is their chief source of income or combined with another source, considering time, capital, and profitability
Standard_of_Review: Assessment of facts and application of statutory criteria
Grounds_for_Claim: Entitlement to deduct farming losses based on classification as class (I) farmer
Outcome_on_Merits: Plaintiff qualifies as a class (I) farmer
Key_Evidence_Considered: Investment of savings, loans taken, hours worked, shift from managerial work, agricultural challenges
Evidence_Type: Financial records, time allocation, loan documents, employment history
Remedy_Requested: Full deduction of farming losses for 1978–1980
Outcome: Allowed full deduction of farming losses

Violation_Type: Failure to meet criteria for Convention refugee status
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration Act - Definition of Convention refugee
Application_Facts: Applicants are of Romani ethnicity and claim discrimination and fear of persecution in Hungary
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of Immigration and Refugee Board decision
Evidence_Used: Availability of state protection mechanisms in Hungary
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence demonstrating persecution beyond discrimination
Insufficient proof of ineffective state protection
Credibility_Assessment: Board found applicants did not establish a well-founded fear of persecution
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution based on race, religion, nationality, social group, or political opinion
Decision_Rationale: Discrimination does not equate to persecution; Hungary provides adequate state protection

Violation_Type: Failure to properly assess credible evidence
Legal_Provision_Violated: Subsection 69.1(9.1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed political persecution in Cameroon due to his father's political activities; provided testimony and documentary evidence
Procedural_Issue: Refugee Division failed to adequately assess objective evidence and improperly dismissed subjective testimony
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient analysis of objective evidence, credibility not properly assessed
Credibility_Assessment: Testimony deemed not credible by Refugee Division without adequate reasoning
Decision_Outcome: Claim rejected due to lack of credible basis for refugee claim
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; original decision quashed
Decision_Rationale: Court found legal error in failure to properly analyze all evidence as required by law
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Was the Board's decision based on credibility patently unreasonable?
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board questioned female applicant's credibility due to lack of supporting evidence and conflicting documents
Evidence_Type: Inconclusive forensic report on IUD register
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of forced abortion and potential sterilization under China's one-child policy
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to disclose previous immigration refusals
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Plausibility of the Board’s credibility assessment
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None found; Board reasonably weighed available evidence
Crimes.Application_Factor: Inconsistent documentation and lack of corroboration
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Alleged inconsistencies in submitted medical records

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 183 of IRPR (implied condition to leave upon expiry)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants remained in Canada after visa expiration while pursuing refugee claims
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Not applicable directly, but credibility concerns affected overall claim
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Timing and admissibility of refugee claims post-overstay
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over judicial review of refugee decisions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of justification for overstay or application delays
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Central to refugee determination; negatively assessed by Board
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refugee status denied; overstay remains violation
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Recognition as refugees and permanent residence
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Quashing of negative decision and referral back
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Credibility doubts undermined claims of persecution

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Was the refusal of refugee status due to credibility issues patently unreasonable?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; work permit refusal upheld
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicants’ claims of forced abortion and sterilization deemed not credible
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Refugee hearing and subsequent judicial review
Crimes.Application_Error: Inconsistencies in narrative and lack of verifiable evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None identified; Board considered all relevant evidence
Crimes.Application_Factor: Failure to provide corroborative evidence for key claims
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim denied, leading to work permit refusal
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Suspected inaccuracies in medical documentation regarding IUD insertion

Application_Facts: Applicant must accumulate at least 1,095 days of residence in Canada within four years preceding application; Mr. Haj-Kamali's absences were miscalculated by up to 136 days
Residency_Compliance: Alleged insufficient physical presence; calculation error and legal test ambiguity identified
Procedural_Issue: Miscalculation of absences, ambiguous application of legal test (physical presence vs. centralized mode of existence)
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Inaccurate calculation of absence days, lack of clarity in interpreting residency
Decision_Outcome: Denial of citizenship application due to insufficient residency
Outcome: Remitted to Citizenship Court for redetermination
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of application with correct factual and legal assessment
Legal_Standard_Applied: Section 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act – 1,095-day residency requirement
Standard_of_Review: Patent unreasonableness (factual findings), Reasonableness simpliciter (mixed fact and law)
Decision_Rationale: Potential factual error in calculating absences and unclear legal standard may have affected outcome

Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Alleged lack of opportunity to present evidence on state protection
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Subjective belief not supported by documentary evidence

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Availability of state protection in country of origin
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's fear deemed subjective and uncorroborated
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Lack of objective evidence supporting police targeting

Crimes.Violation_Type: Inability to access state protection due to employer coercion
Crimes.Governing_Law: Canadian immigration law and international refugee principles
Crimes.Application_Facts: Claimant feared persecution by employer with alleged state complicity
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Insufficient evidence to prove state protection unavailability

Application_Facts: Applicants fled Colombia after FARC demanded money, fearing for their lives.
Procedural_Issue: Board questioned credibility due to meeting FARC, not reporting threats, and quick departure.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board assumed adequate state protection without sufficient evidence analysis.
Credibility_Assessment: Credibility findings based on implausible actions without considering context.
Decision_Outcome: Board denied refugee status based on credibility and state protection issues.
Outcome: Judicial review granted; case remanded to a different Board member.
Legal_Standard_Applied: Refugee claimants must overcome presumption of state protection unless clear evidence shows otherwise.
Decision_Rationale: Findings on credibility and state protection were unreasonable.

Criminality_Severity: High – credible fear of retaliation and death
Risk_Assessment: Significant risk due to targeted threats from FARC
Targeted_Victimization: Yes – based on profession and perceived financial capacity
Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient contextual evidence of FARC threats
Evidence_Credibility: Applicants provided plausible explanations; Board failed to properly assess
Credibility_Assessment: Board unreasonably dismissed credibility despite coherent narrative

Sub_Crime_Type: Threat of kidnapping by armed group
Aggravating_Factors: History of FARC abductions for ransom or political leverage
Criminality_Severity: High – pattern of forced disappearances and abductions
Risk_Assessment: Elevated risk due to presence of FARC and lack of state control
Targeted_Victimization: Yes – professionals seen as financially viable targets
Evidence_Sufficiency: Contextual evidence supports risk; personal threats reported
Credibility_Assessment: Board’s skepticism not supported by contradictory evidence

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of credibility and state protection findings
Evidence_Assessment: Board failed to consider local context and specific risks
Decision_Outcome: Negative determination on credibility and state protection
Burden_of_Proof: On claimant to rebut presumption of state protection
Credibility_Factor: Implausibility of meeting FARC without detention questioned
Legal_Rule: Credibility findings require clear contradictions or implausibilities
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution by FARC due to extortion demands
Key_Evidence_Considered: Applicants’ testimony, expert reports on Colombia
Legal_Framework: Refugee Convention, IRPA, jurisprudence on state protection
Defendant_Response: Board maintained denial based on credibility and protection assumptions

Criminality_Severity: High – part of systematic exploitation by insurgent group
Risk_Assessment: Serious and ongoing risk due to failure of state to protect
Risk_Nature: Forced financial contribution under threat of violence
Targeted_Victimization: Yes – based on profession and perceived wealth
Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient evidence of extortion pattern and personal threat
Evidence_Credibility: Explanations consistent with known conditions in Colombia

Application_Facts: The Applicants' refugee claims were dismissed by the RPD and upheld by the RAD, prompting a judicial review.
Procedural_Issue: The RAD erred by applying a reasonableness standard instead of conducting an independent assessment.
Outcome: Judicial review granted, matter referred back to a different RAD panel
Remedy_Sought: Independent reassessment by a different RAD panel
Decision_Rationale: The RAD has equal expertise to the RPD in assessing documentary evidence and must conduct an independent assessment rather than reviewing for reasonableness.

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the immigration officer erred in assessing the genuineness of the applicant's marriage
Crimes.Outcome: Application for judicial review allowed; case remanded for reconsideration by a different officer
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer found inconsistencies in interview answers but some were minor
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence was strong; inconsistencies in interview responses
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section related to genuineness of marriage under IRPA
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Marriage sponsorship application denied due to doubts about genuineness
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of transparency and justification in officer's decision
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to adequately justify rejection of applicant's explanations
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Strong documentary evidence downplayed despite minor inconsistencies
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Marriage must be genuine and not entered into for immigration purposes
Crimes.Application_Factor: Nature and consistency of relationship evidence

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act - compliance with removal orders
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant failed to leave Canada per removal order and applied for permanent residence under spousal class
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to comply with removal order
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Doubts about genuineness of marriage in spousal sponsorship application
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Officer inadequately explained rejection of applicant’s justifications
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Minor inconsistencies not properly contextualized; lack of explanation for rejecting evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer doubted marriage genuineness based on inconsistent answers
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision found unreasonable; case remanded for redetermination
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed; case sent back for new assessment
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent resident status under spousal class
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of application by a different officer
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Lack of transparency and inadequate justification rendered decision unreasonable
